subject: PE Today: Covering Virginia Tech
body:
CBSNews.com












In 
      The Virginia Tech Tragedy, What Is The Right Amount Of 
      Coverage?There is little doubt that the coverage has, at 
      times, seemed repetitious – though it's somewhat unfair to blame news 
      outlets for that fact, as they have had a lot of airtime to fill, and have 
      largely done so admirably. My only complaint is that, in the early going, 
      there was more discussion about who we should blame than seemed 
      appropriate so soon after the tragedy. [+ Read More]

A 
      "Massacre" Or A "Tragedy?"Today, CBS News made the decision 
      to stop referring to the Virginia Tech shootings as a "massacre." Instead, 
      the outlet will use the word "tragedy." The change in terminology shifts 
      focus from the horror of the shootings to the sadness they have caused. 
      "Massacre" is a dramatic word that evokes slaughter; "tragedy" is more 
      passive, less tied to an individual 
      act. [+ Read More]

CBSNews.com 
      Adopts Abortion Terminology If not for the Virginia Tech 
      tragedy, the top story on CBSNews.com right now would likely be the 
      decision by the Supreme Court to uphold the Partial Birth Abortion Ban 
      Act. People on opposite sides of contentious issues like this often use 
      certain terminology to try to frame the debate – see the "death tax" vs. 
      "estate tax" argument. In this case, some, including President Bush, 
      prefer the phrase "partial birth abortion," while others favor "late term 
      abortion."[+ Read More]
